claim: Around 60% of individuals with neurodevelopmental disorders (NDD) remain undiagnosed after comprehensive genetic testing, primarily of protein-coding genes
source: Around 60% of individuals with neurodevelopmental disorders (NDD) remain undiagnosed after comprehensive genetic testing, primarily of protein-coding genes1.
evidence: Cited from reference 1, representing established knowledge in the field

claim: RNU4-2 encodes the U4 small nuclear RNA (snRNA), which is a critical component of the U4/U6.U5 tri-snRNP complex of the major spliceosome
source: RNU4-2 encodes the U4 small nuclear RNA (snRNA), which is a critical component of the U4/U6.U5 tri-snRNP complex of the major spliceosome2.
evidence: Cited from reference 2, representing established knowledge about RNU4-2 function

claim: An 18 base pair region of RNU4-2 mapping to two structural elements in the U4/U6 snRNA duplex (the T-loop and stem III) is severely depleted of variation in the general population
source: We identify an 18 base pair region of RNU4-2 mapping to two structural elements in the U4/U6 snRNA duplex (the T-loop and stem III) that is severely depleted of variation in the general population
evidence: Based on analysis of population variant data from UK Biobank showing depletion

claim: 115 individuals with NDD have heterozygous variants in the 18 bp critical region of RNU4-2
source: we identify heterozygous variants in 115 individuals with NDD
evidence: Direct count from study cohorts

claim: 77.4% of individuals with RNU4-2 variants have the same highly recurrent single base insertion (n.64_65insT)
source: Most individuals (77.4%) have the same highly recurrent single base insertion (n.64_65insT).
evidence: Direct calculation from study data: 89 out of 115 individuals

claim: In 54 individuals in whom parental allele of origin could be determined, all de novo variants were on the maternal allele
source: In 54 individuals in whom it could be determined, the de novo variants were all on the maternal allele.
evidence: Direct observation from phasing analysis

claim: RNU4-2 is highly expressed in the developing human brain, in contrast to RNU4-1 and other U4 homologues
source: We demonstrate that RNU4-2 is highly expressed in the developing human brain, in contrast to RNU4-1 and other U4 homologues.
evidence: Based on RNA-seq expression analysis from BrainVar dataset

claim: 5′ splice-site use is systematically disrupted in individuals with RNU4-2 variants
source: Using RNA sequencing, we show how 5′ splice-site use is systematically disrupted in individuals with RNU4-2 variants
evidence: RNA-seq analysis from blood samples of 5 individuals with RNU4-2 variants

claim: Variants in the 18 base pair region of RNU4-2 explain 0.4% of individuals with NDD
source: Finally, we estimate that variants in this 18 base pair region explain 0.4% of individuals with NDD.
evidence: Calculated estimate based on GEL cohort data accounting for pre-existing diagnostic yield

claim: Non-coding RNAs comprise 37.4% of processed exonic RNA sequence in humans
source: Non-coding RNAs, which comprise 37.4% of processed exonic RNA sequence in humans5
evidence: Cited from reference 5

claim: RNU12 variants cause autosomal recessive early-onset cerebellar ataxia
source: RNU12 variants cause autosomal recessive early-onset cerebellar ataxia9
evidence: Cited from reference 9

claim: RNU4ATAC variants cause an autosomal recessive multisystem congenital disorder including microcephaly, growth retardation and developmental delay
source: RNU4ATAC variants cause an autosomal recessive multisystem congenital disorder including microcephaly, growth retardation and developmental delay (eponyms include Taybi Linder10, Lowry–Wood11 and Roifman syndromes12)
evidence: Cited from references 10, 11, and 12

claim: The n.64_65insT variant was initially identified as arising de novo in 38 probands recruited for genome sequencing with their unaffected parents
source: This variant was initially identified as arising de novo in 38 probands recruited for genome sequencing with their unaffected parents13.
evidence: Direct count from GEL high-confidence de novo variant dataset

claim: 46 individuals with the n.64_65insT variant were identified in 8,841 probands with undiagnosed NDD in GEL, corresponding to 0.52%
source: All of the 46 individuals with the variant have undiagnosed NDD (categorized as global developmental delay, intellectual disability and/or autism spectrum disorder), corresponding to 0.52% of 8,841 probands with so far undiagnosed NDD in GEL.
evidence: Direct count and percentage calculation from GEL cohort

claim: The n.64_65insT variant was not found in any of 3,408 NDD probands with an existing genetic diagnosis
source: The n.64_65insT variant was not found in any of 3,408 NDD probands with an existing genetic diagnosis
evidence: Direct observation from GEL cohort analysis

claim: The n.64_65insT variant was not found in 21,817 probands with non-NDD phenotypes in GEL
source: The n.64_65insT variant was not found in any of 3,408 NDD probands with an existing genetic diagnosis, 21,817 probands with non-NDD phenotypes
evidence: Direct observation from GEL cohort analysis

claim: The n.64_65insT variant was not found in 33,122 unaffected individuals in GEL
source: The n.64_65insT variant was not found in any of 3,408 NDD probands with an existing genetic diagnosis, 21,817 probands with non-NDD phenotypes or 33,122 unaffected individuals.
evidence: Direct observation from GEL cohort analysis

claim: Individuals with the n.64_65insT variant are significantly enriched for global developmental delay (n = 37; OR = 3.56; P = 2.75 × 10−4)
source: Individuals with the variant are significantly enriched for global developmental delay (n = 37; odds ratio (OR) = 3.56; Fisher's P = 2.75 × 10−4)
evidence: Statistical analysis comparing phenotypes in individuals with variant to all other NDD probands

claim: Individuals with the n.64_65insT variant are significantly enriched for delayed gross motor development (n = 26; OR = 2.55; P = 1.64 × 10−3)
source: delayed gross motor development (n = 26; OR = 2.55; P = 1.64 × 10−3)
evidence: Statistical analysis comparing phenotypes in individuals with variant to all other NDD probands

claim: Individuals with the n.64_65insT variant are significantly enriched for microcephaly (n = 26; OR = 6.62; P = 7.87 × 10−10)
source: microcephaly (n = 26; OR = 6.62; P = 7.87 × 10−10)
evidence: Statistical analysis comparing phenotypes in individuals with variant to all other NDD probands

claim: Individuals with the n.64_65insT variant are significantly enriched for delayed fine motor development (n = 24; OR = 2.61; P = 1.69 × 10−3)
source: delayed fine motor development (n = 24; OR = 2.61; P = 1.69 × 10−3)
evidence: Statistical analysis comparing phenotypes in individuals with variant to all other NDD probands

claim: Individuals with the n.64_65insT variant are significantly enriched for hypotonia (n = 18; OR = 3.60; P = 7.09 × 10−5)
evidence: Statistical analysis comparing phenotypes in individuals with variant to all other NDD probands

claim: Individuals with the n.64_65insT variant are significantly enriched for short stature (n = 15; OR = 3.54; P = 2.17 × 10−4)
source: short stature (n = 15; OR = 3.54; P = 2.17 × 10−4)
evidence: Statistical analysis comparing phenotypes in individuals with variant to all other NDD probands

claim: Individuals with the n.64_65insT variant are significantly enriched for drooling (n = 7; OR = 19.2; P = 2.83 × 10−7)
evidence: Statistical analysis comparing phenotypes in individuals with variant to all other NDD probands

claim: Individuals with the n.64_65insT variant are significantly enriched for absent speech (n = 6; OR = 6.23; P = 7.45 × 10−4)
source: absent speech (n = 6; OR = 6.23; P = 7.45 × 10−4)
evidence: Statistical analysis comparing phenotypes in individuals with variant to all other NDD probands

claim: The n.64_65insT variant is not found in 76,215 genome-sequenced individuals in gnomAD v.4.0
source: The n.64_65insT variant is not found in 76,215 genome-sequenced individuals in gnomAD v.4.0 (ref. 14)
evidence: Direct observation from gnomAD database

claim: The n.64_65insT variant is not found in 245,400 individuals in the All of Us dataset
source: or in 245,400 individuals in the All of Us dataset15
evidence: Direct observation from All of Us database

claim: The n.64_65insT variant is seen in a single individual in the UK Biobank (allele frequency of 1.02 × 10−6)
source: It is seen in a single individual in the UK Biobank16 (allele frequency of 1.02 × 10−6)
evidence: Direct observation from UK Biobank data

claim: The critical 18 bp region shows 26% of all possible SNVs observed in UK Biobank compared to a median of 78% across the rest of the gene
source: The recurrent n.64_65insT variant resides within the central region of RNU4-2, towards the 5′ end of an 18 bp region that is depleted of variants in population datasets compared with the rest of the gene (26% of all possible single nucleotide variants (SNVs) observed in UK Biobank compared to a median of 78% across the rest of the gene
evidence: Analysis of variant density in UK Biobank data

claim: 61 individuals with variants in the critical region were identified in GEL (60 probands and one sibling)
source: In total, we identified 115 individuals with variants across this region, including 61 individuals in GEL (60 probands and one more sibling)
evidence: Direct count from GEL cohort

claim: 54 individuals with variants in the critical region were identified from extra cohorts beyond GEL
source: In total, we identified 115 individuals with variants across this region, including 61 individuals in GEL (60 probands and one more sibling) and 54 from extra cohorts
evidence: Direct count from multiple cohorts

claim: For 86 of the 115 individuals, sequencing data for both parents were available to confirm that the variants had arisen de novo
source: For 86 of the 115 individuals, sequencing data for both parents were available to confirm that the variants had arisen de novo.
evidence: Direct count from trio sequencing data

claim: Single base insertion variants in the critical region are strongly enriched in individuals with NDD: 54 out of 8,841 (0.61%) GEL undiagnosed NDD probands compared to 2 out of 490,132 individuals in the UK Biobank (OR = 1,531; 95% CI: 404–16,384; P = 3.3 × 10−92)
source: Single base insertion variants in this region are strongly enriched in individuals with NDD: 54 out of 8,841 (0.61%) GEL undiagnosed NDD probands (55 out of 10,388 individuals) have single base insertions compared to two out of 490,132 individuals in the UK Biobank (OR = 1,531; 95% confidence interval (CI): 404–16,384; Fisher's P = 3.3 × 10−92).
evidence: Statistical comparison between GEL NDD cohort and UK Biobank

claim: There is a modest enrichment of SNVs in GEL NDD probands across the critical region (undiagnosed NDD: 6 out of 8,841; UK Biobank: 35 out of 490,132; OR = 9.51; 95%CI: 3.27–22.8; P = 8.16 × 10−5)
source: Aside from insertions, there is also a modest enrichment of SNVs in GEL NDD probands across the critical region (undiagnosed NDD: six out of 8,841; UK Biobank: 35 out of 490,132; OR = 9.51; 95%CI: 3.27–22.8; Fisher's P = 8.16 × 10−5).
evidence: Statistical comparison between GEL NDD cohort and UK Biobank

claim: 15 individuals across cohorts were identified with SNVs in the critical region (10 confirmed de novo)
source: We identified 15 individuals across cohorts with SNVs in this region (Extended Data Table 1; 10 confirmed de novo)
evidence: Direct count from multiple cohorts

claim: Across the remainder of RNU4-2 there is no significant enrichment of variants in undiagnosed NDD probands when compared with non-NDD probands (194 out of 7,519 undiagnosed NDD; 521 out of 19,428 non-NDD; OR = 0.96; 95%CI: 0.81–1.14; P = 0.67)
source: Across the remainder of RNU4-2 there is no significant enrichment of variants in undiagnosed NDD probands when compared with non-NDD probands (194 out of 7,519 undiagnosed NDD; 521 out of 19,428 non-NDD in GEL aggregated variant dataset17; OR = 0.96; 95%CI: 0.81–1.14; Fisher's P = 0.67).
evidence: Statistical comparison within GEL cohort

claim: 60 out of 8,841, or 0.68%, of all genetically undiagnosed NDD probands in GEL have variants in the 18 bp critical region
source: This includes 60 out of 8,841, or 0.68%, of all genetically undiagnosed NDD probands in GEL.
evidence: Direct count and percentage calculation from GEL cohort

claim: Variants in the critical region are observed in 39 out of 490,132 (0.008%) individuals in the UK Biobank (OR = 85.8; 95%CI: 56.4–131.6; P = 1.84 × 10−78)
source: By contrast, variants in this region are observed in 39 out of 490,132 (0.008%) individuals in the UK Biobank (OR = 85.8; 95%CI: 56.4–131.6; Fisher's P = 1.84 × 10−78).
evidence: Statistical comparison between GEL NDD cohort and UK Biobank

claim: The five individuals with RNU4-2 variants had more abnormal splicing events than 378 control individuals with non-NDD phenotypes (mean 21.6 versus 4.5; Wilcoxon P = 0.0126)
source: The five individuals with RNU4-2 variants had more abnormal splicing events than 378 control individuals with non-NDD phenotypes (mean 21.6 versus 4.5; Wilcoxon P = 0.0126)
evidence: RNA-seq analysis comparing individuals with RNU4-2 variants to controls

claim: The most pronounced difference in RNA-seq was observed for abnormal splicing events corresponding to increased use of unannotated 5′ splice sites (mean 8.8 events in individuals with RNU4-2 variants compared with 0.7 in both 378 unmatched controls and ten matched controls; Wilcoxon P = 4.0 × 10−5 and P = 5.7 × 10−3, respectively)
source: Consistent with the importance of the critical region in 5′ splice-site recognition, the most pronounced difference was observed for abnormal splicing events corresponding to increased use of unannotated 5′ splice sites (mean 8.8 events in individuals with RNU4-2 variants compared with 0.7 in both 378 unmatched controls and ten controls matched on genetic ancestry, sex and age at consent; Wilcoxon P = 4.0 × 10−5 and P = 5.7 × 10−3, respectively
evidence: RNA-seq analysis comparing individuals with RNU4-2 variants to controls

claim: Detailed phenotypic information was collected for 49 individuals (42 with n.64_65insT, three with other single base insertions, and four with SNVs)
source: To characterize the phenotypic spectrum associated with variants in RNU4-2, we collected detailed phenotypic information for a subset of 49 individuals (42 with n.64_65insT, three with other single base insertions, and four with SNVs
evidence: Direct count from clinical data collection

claim: All 49 phenotyped individuals have moderate to severe global developmental delay and intellectual disability
source: Using these data, we find the RNU4-2 syndromic NDD to be characterized by moderate to severe global developmental delay (four children with SNVs with moderate delay) and intellectual disability in all individuals.
evidence: Clinical phenotype data from 49 individuals

claim: 83% of phenotyped individuals achieved ambulation but at a delayed age (average 3.4 years, range 17 months to 7.5 years)
source: Most (83%) achieved ambulation but at a delayed age (average 3.4 years, range 17 months to 7.5 years)
evidence: Clinical phenotype data from 49 individuals

claim: Only three individuals (two with an SNV) had fluent speech
source: Only three individuals (two with an SNV) had fluent speech
evidence: Clinical phenotype data from 49 individuals

claim: All but three phenotyped individuals were reported to have dysmorphic facial features
source: All but three were reported to have dysmorphic facial features.
evidence: Clinical phenotype data from 49 individuals

claim: Children with SNVs had fewer reports of severe global developmental delay (0 out of 4 versus 34 out of 40, Fisher's P = 0.0015)
source: In comparison to the single base insertions, children with SNVs had fewer reports of severe global developmental delay (zero out of four versus 34 out of 40, Fisher's P = 0.0015).
evidence: Statistical comparison of phenotypes between SNV and insertion groups

claim: 3,408 out of 13,450 individuals (25.3%) in the DDD cohort have at least one read mapping to the position of the n.64_65insT variant in exome sequencing data
source: Across the DDD cohort, 3,408 out of 13,450 individuals (25.3%) have at least one read mapping to the position of the n.64_65insT variant
evidence: Analysis of exome sequencing coverage in DDD cohort

claim: Of 1,755 individuals in both GEL and DDD, 22 have the n.64_65insT variant (1.3%)
source: Of 1,755 individuals in both GEL and DDD, 22 have the n.64_65insT variant (1.3%).
evidence: Direct count from overlapping cohort analysis

claim: Two of the 22 individuals with n.64_65insT in both GEL and DDD (9.1%) each have a single read at the variant position in the exome sequencing data from DDD
source: Two of the 22 individuals (9.1%) each have a single read at the variant position in the exome sequencing data from DDD
evidence: Analysis of exome sequencing reads in DDD cohort

claim: RNU4-2 and RNU4-1 are contiguous on chr. 12, both 141 bp long and highly homologous, differing by four nucleotides (97.2% similarity)
source: RNU4-2 and RNU4-1 are contiguous on chr. 12, both 141 bp long and highly homologous, differing by four nucleotides (97.2% similarity).
evidence: Genomic sequence comparison

claim: RNU4-2 is consistently expressed at a significantly higher level than RNU4-1 in the prefrontal cortex
source: The expression of RNU4-1 and RNU4-2 is tightly correlated (Supplementary Fig. 5), however, RNU4-2 is consistently expressed at a significantly higher level than RNU4-1 (Fig. 5a).
evidence: RNA-seq expression analysis from BrainVar dataset

claim: The largest proportion of NDD explained by a single gene in 13,449 individuals in the DDD cohort was 0.68% for ANKRD11
source: As a comparison, the largest proportion of NDD explained by a single gene in 13,449 individuals in the DDD cohort1 was 0.68% for ANKRD11
evidence: Cited from reference 1 (DDD cohort analysis)

claim: The rate of RNU4-2 variants is much lower in cohorts recruited primarily for autism spectrum disorder (three out of 7,149; 0.042% across the SSC, SPARK and MSSNG cohorts)
source: This is consistent with the much lower rate of RNU4-2 variants in cohorts recruited primarily for autism spectrum disorder (for example, three out of 7,149; 0.042% across the Simons Simplex Collection (SSC)24, SPARK25 and MSSNG26).
evidence: Direct count from autism cohorts

claim: The most recurrent protein-coding variant in a dataset of 31,058 individuals with developmental disorders is observed in 36 individuals (0.12%; GRCh38:chr. 11: 66211206:C:T; PACS1:p.Arg203Trp)
source: By contrast, the most recurrent protein-coding variant in a dataset of 31,058 individuals with developmental disorders29 is observed in 36 individuals (0.12%; GRCh38:chr. 11: 66211206:C:T; PACS1:p.Arg203Trp).
evidence: Cited from reference 29

claim: There is no association between maternal age and the n.64_65insT variant in GEL (mean 30.2 compared to 29.7 across other NDD probands)
source: We do not see an association with maternal age for individuals with n.64_65insT in GEL (mean 30.2 compared to 29.7 across other NDD probands; Extended Data Fig. 4).
evidence: Statistical comparison of maternal age between groups

claim: A median of 76% of all possible SNVs in RNU4-2 are observed in UK Biobank compared with 13% on average in intergenic sequences of the same length (141 bp; P < 0.001)
source: A median of 76% of all possible SNVs in RNU4-2 are observed compared with 13% on average in the intergenic sequences of the same length (141 bp; P < 0.001, Monte Carlo Fisher-Pitman test).
evidence: Statistical comparison of variant density between RNU4-2 and intergenic regions

claim: All observed variants in RNU4-2 in the UK Biobank are very rare (maximum allele frequency 0.025%)
source: Despite the high number of variants in RNU4-2 in the UK Biobank, there are no individuals with homozygous variants and all observed variants are very rare (maximum allele frequency 0.025%)
evidence: Analysis of variant frequencies in UK Biobank

claim: There are no individuals with homozygous variants in RNU4-2 in the UK Biobank
source: Despite the high number of variants in RNU4-2 in the UK Biobank, there are no individuals with homozygous variants
evidence: Analysis of genotypes in UK Biobank

claim: Eleven of 12 shared abnormal splicing events (91.6%) in individuals with RNU4-2 variants corresponded to an increase in unannotated 5′ splice-site use
source: Eleven of these 12 events (91.6%) corresponded to an increase in unannotated 5′ splice-site use.
evidence: RNA-seq analysis of shared splicing events

claim: None of the 12 shared abnormal splicing events were identified in any of the 378 controls
source: None of these shared events were identified in any of the 378 controls.
evidence: RNA-seq analysis comparing cases to controls

claim: When randomly sampling five control individuals across 10,000 permutations, the mean number of events shared by two or more individuals was 0.007, significantly fewer than the 12 in RNU4-2 individuals (permutation P < 1 × 10−4)
source: By contrast, when randomly sampling five control individuals across 10,000 permutations, the mean number of events shared by two or more individuals was 0.007, significantly fewer than the 12 in RNU4-2 individuals (permutation P < 1 × 10−4
evidence: Permutation testing of shared splicing events

claim: Five of the genes implicated in the 12 shared splicing events are in the DDG2P database and/or were associated with NDD in a previous large-scale analysis (NDUFV1, H2AC6, JMJD1C, MAP4K4 and SF1)
source: Five of the genes implicated in the 12 shared events are in the Developmental Disorders Genotype-to-Phenotype (DDG2P) database21 and/or were associated with NDD in a previous large-scale analysis22 (NDUFV1, H2AC6, JMJD1C, MAP4K4 and SF1).
evidence: Cross-reference with DDG2P database and previous NDD study

claim: Ten of the 12 shared splicing events affect the protein-coding sequence, with four predicted to cause a frameshift
source: Ten of the 12 shared events affect the protein-coding sequence, with four predicted to cause a frameshift
evidence: Analysis of predicted consequences of shared splicing events

claim: Unannotated 5′ splice sites with increased use have an increase in T at the +3 position (8 out of 19 versus 0 out of 36; Fisher's P = 6.2 × 10−5; OR = Inf; 95%CI: 5.92-Inf)
source: 5′ splice sites with increased use (top) have an increase in T at the +3 position (eight out of 19 versus zero out of 36; Fisher's P = 6.2 × 10−5; OR = Inf; 95%CI: 5.92-Inf)
evidence: Sequence motif analysis of 5′ splice sites from RNA-seq data

claim: Unannotated 5′ splice sites with increased use have an increase in C at the +4 position (4 out of 19 versus 0 out of 36; Fisher's P = 0.011; OR = Inf; 95%CI: 1.37-Inf)
source: an increase in C at the +4 (four out of 19 versus zero out of 36; Fisher's P = 0.011; OR = Inf; 95%CI: 1.37-Inf)
evidence: Sequence motif analysis of 5′ splice sites from RNA-seq data

claim: Unannotated 5′ splice sites with increased use have an increase in C at the +5 position (6 out of 19 versus 1 out of 36; Fisher's P = 0.0051; OR = 15.3; 95%CI: 2.09-Inf)
source: and +5 (six out of 19 versus 1/36; Fisher's P = 0.0051; OR = 15.3; 95%CI: 2.09-Inf)) positions compared to decreased 5′ splice sites
evidence: Sequence motif analysis of 5′ splice sites from RNA-seq data

claim: The 18 bp critical region of RNU4-2 is defined as chr. 12: 120291825–120291842
source: On the basis of the population variant data, we defined a critical, highly constrained region as chr. 12: 120291825–120291842.
evidence: Definition based on variant depletion analysis

claim: The highly recurrent n.64_65insT variant is located at GRCh38:chr. 12: 120291839:T:TA
source: We identified a highly recurrent single base insertion (GRCh38:chr. 12: 120291839:T:TA; n.64_65insT) in RNU4-2 in GEL1.
evidence: Genomic coordinates from variant calling

claim: The recurrent n.77_78insT variant is located at GRCh38:chr. 12: 120291826:T:TA and is seen in six individuals, two of whom are affected siblings
source: including n.77_78insT (GRCh38:chr. 12: 120291826:T:TA), which is seen in six individuals, two of whom are affected siblings.
evidence: Genomic coordinates and count from variant calling

claim: The protein-coding genome comprises roughly 1.5% of the total genome
source: So far, most known disease-causing variants are in the roughly 1.5% of the genome that directly encodes proteins3.
evidence: Cited from reference 3, representing established knowledge

claim: The non-coding genome makes up 98.5% of the total genome
source: By contrast, the non-coding genome (which makes up the remaining 98.5%) has been relatively unexplored
evidence: Calculated as complement to protein-coding genome percentage

claim: The GEL cohort includes 8,841 probands with genetically undiagnosed NDD
source: Using a cohort of 8,841 probands with genetically undiagnosed NDD in the Genomics England 100,000 genomes project (GEL)4
evidence: Direct count from GEL cohort definition

claim: The critical region maps to U4 nucleotides 62–79
source: The 18 bp critical region in RNU4-2 maps to a region of U4 between the stem I region of complementary base pairing to U6 and the 3′ stem–loop structures (nucleotides 62–79
evidence: Mapping based on structural analysis

claim: The critical region is loaded into the active site of the SNRNP200-encoded BRR2 helicase
source: This region is known to be loaded into the active site of the SNRNP200-encoded BRR2 helicase, which mediates spliceosome activation by unwinding the U4/U6 duplex2.
evidence: Cited from reference 2, representing established structural knowledge

claim: The BrainVar dataset includes bulk-tissue RNA-seq data from 176 de-identified postmortem samples of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex or frontal cerebral wall
source: This dataset includes bulk-tissue RNA-seq data from 176 de-identified postmortem samples of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC, n = 167 older than ten postconception weeks) or frontal cerebral wall (n = 9 younger than ten postconception weeks), ranging from six postconception weeks to 20 years of age.
evidence: Description of BrainVar dataset composition
